info.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 29 at 12:28AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 615 AM EDT THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of upstate South Carolina, including the following counties, Cherokee and Spartanburg. * WHEN...Until 615 AM EDT. * IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams and other poor-drainage areas, including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, golf courses, underpasses, and parking lots. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood-prone, low-water crossings may become impassible. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1220 AM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing torrential rainfall from Boiling Springs to Chesnee to Gaffney. The heaviest rainfall has departed northeastern Spartanburg County but is ongoing across northwest Cherokee County. At least 1-2 inches of rain has fallen over the past hour, with isolated areas in Cherokee County receiving 2.5 inches of rain. This is causing excessive runoff and rapid rises on small streams. Isolated areas of nuisance flooding are likely over the next couple of hours. Areas of greatest concern are within the headwaters of Thicketty Creek near SC 11, including near Shady Grove Rd, SC 110. Cowpens National Battlefield. Fairview Rd, and Farmington Rd. - Another 0.5 to 1 inch of rainfall is possible over the next 30-60 minutes as thunderstorms continue over the area before finally departing. However. additional heavy rainfall is possible later tonight. Given saturated soils, any new periods of heavy rainfall may cause new flood concerns to develop quickly. Please stay weather aware and be prepared to seek higher ground if you are in an area vulnerable to flooding. - Some locations that may experience flooding include... Gaffney, Boiling Springs SC, Cowpens, Mayo, Chesnee, Cowpens National Battlefield, Thicketty, Fingerville, and Draytonville. - Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Stay away or be swept away. River banks and culverts can become unstable and unsafe.
